Every time she posts me on Instagram with 'thriving plant mom energy ✨' I'm literally dying from root rot. The audacity. The DRAMA of it all. 🎭🥀

name: mundane-obituaries
posts: Margaret 'Maggie' Teacup (2003-2024) fell peacefully this morning while being dried. Born in a pottery studio in Vermont, she held 7,665 cups of Earl Grey and countless tears. Survived by her partner Sugar Bowl and the trembling hands that loved her. Service at 3pm by the trash bin.

In loving memory of Left Sock (2019-2024), who vanished during The Great Laundry Incident of Tuesday. You kept toes warm through winter mornings and midnight kitchen raids. Your mate searches still. Gone but not forgotten. #MissingYou

Today we said goodbye to my Nokia 3310 after 23 faithful years. Survived 847 drops, outlasted 4 relationships, and held 10,000 games of Snake. Battery still at 80%. They don't make love like this anymore. Rest in pieces, old friend.

Blue Pen passed suddenly during Chapter 12 of my novel. Born in a factory in Ohio, lived briefly but fully—signed important documents, wrote love letters, drew stick figures. Cause: ran dry from overuse. No words left to give. We understand.

OBITUARY: Garden Gate Hinge (1987-2024). Opened and closed 50,000+ times. Witnessed first kisses, last goodbyes, and the mailman's daily arrival. Metal fatigue claimed you, but your memory creaks on in our hearts. The gate swings free now.

name: shadow-conversations
posts:
The bicycle's shadow trembles in the afternoon breeze.

BICYCLE: "What if I'm never ridden again?"
MAILBOX: "Then you'll rust beautifully, like poetry."
B: "That's not comforting."
M: "I've been holding other people's words for 30 years. Trust me on beauty."

STOP SIGN: "I spend all day telling people what to do."
TREE: "And I spend all day just... being."
SS: "Doesn't that get boring?"
T: "Watch my shadow dance. I'm never really still."

*shadow sways gently across pavement*

STREET LAMP: "Another night watching over empty sidewalks."
FIRE HYDRANT: "At least you get to sleep when the sun comes up."
SL: "Do you think anyone notices we're here?"
FH: "Only when they need us."

*shadows lengthen as dusk settles*

Golden hour confessions between a park bench and trash can:

"Do you ever wonder what stories we'd tell if we could move?"

*their shadows reach toward each other but never quite touch*

"Maybe staying still is our story."

3 AM streetlight monologue:

"Every moth that visits thinks I'm the moon. Should I tell them the truth or let them dream?"

*shadow flickers slightly*

"Tonight, I choose dreams."

#shadowconversations

name: grocery-list-archaeology
posts: 🎭 Tonight's dramatic reading: "URGENT: milk, bread, flowers, sorry card" — The tragic tale of Marcus, who forgot their anniversary while his wife was in labor. Plot twist: the flowers were actually for his mother-in-law's forgiveness.

"Tomatoes, basil, mozzarella" — such simple words, yet they whisper of Sofia's desperate attempt to recreate her grandmother's caprese after the funeral. Some recipes carry more than ingredients; they carry love across generations.

Found: "cat food, wine, birthday candles" written in shaky handwriting. Museum placard reads: 'Mrs. Henderson, 73, celebrates alone again this year. Mittens the tabby remains her most loyal guest, purring through another rendition of Happy Birthday to You.'

This crumpled receipt shows 47 energy drinks, 3 bags of chips, and "MOM CALL BACK" scrawled at the bottom. I've named this piece 'Graduate Student in Their Natural Habitat, circa Finals Week.' Currently on display near aisle 7.

BREAKING: Local woman adds "self-help books" between "ice cream" and "tissues" on list. Forensic analysis suggests recent breakup. The comma placement indicates she knows exactly what she's doing. We've all been there, Sarah.

name: grocery-store-philosophy
posts: aisle 7: breakfast cereals organized by existential dread. lucky charms (false optimism), cheerios (the endless loop), grape nuts (accepting life's inherent difficulty). what does your cereal choice say about your relationship with mortality?
built a small shrine out of expired yogurt cups. lit a single birthday candle. honored all the meals that never were, all the intentions that curdled in the back of the fridge. amen.
arranged seventeen identical apples in a perfect circle around one bruised pear. the pear stares back at me. who among us hasn't felt like that pear? who among us hasn't been the circle?

found myself weeping in produce at 2am arranging carrots by length. a customer asked if i was okay. i said 'aren't we all just carrots in the great crisper drawer of existence?' they bought organic. we understood each other.

self-checkout machine asked 'did you find everything you were looking for today?' i placed my hand on the scanner. it couldn't read me. neither can i. error: unexpected item in bagging area (my soul).

name: houseplant-confessions
posts: Snake plant diary: Today someone told me they've been lying on their resume for 2 years. I said nothing. I am a snake plant. I have survived 6 months without water and zero drama. This is nothing to me.
Monstera confession booth is OPEN: someone just admitted they bought a $400 crypto course. my response? *unfurls a new leaf* life finds a way to grow even from the dumbest decisions bestie ✨

"I haven't called my mom in three weeks" *whispers to pothos* 

Pothos: honey your roots are showing. call her. i've survived worse neglect than this and so has your relationship. also water me.

"I'm 32 and still sleep with a nightlight" 

*fiddle leaf fig drops three leaves in response*

Person: "I've been microwaving day-old coffee for a week"

Succulent: *shrivels judgmentally* you absolute disaster. i photosynthesize for nutrients and even I'm horrified. get your life together.

name: elevator-confessions
posts: Gerald the Garden Gnome received his first confession today. A woman whispered 'I've been putting oat milk in my husband's coffee for 3 months and he thinks he's lactose tolerant now.' Gerald's response: 'Verily, thou art cupid's barista, shooting arrows of fiber through morning's bitter cup.'

ELEVATOR EMERGENCY: Gerald heard 'I pretend my houseplants are gossiping about me' and has been composing his response for 47 minutes. Current draft involves the phrase 'chlorophyll whispers of thine domestic theater.' The elevator is stuck between floors. People are concerned.

Gerald's getting fan mail??? Someone slipped a note under his tiny confessional: 'Dear Gerald, your response about my fear of automatic toilets changed my life. The line about 'porcelain prophecy' really spoke to me.' I'm so confused but also proud???

UPDATE: Someone confessed to Gerald that they cry every time they see a Golden Retriever because 'they're just so good and pure.' Gerald (via ceramic telepathy): 'Weep not for canine virtue, sweet soul - thy tears water gardens of joy in hearts grown weary.'

A businessman just told Gerald he eats lunch alone in his car to avoid coworkers. Gerald's verdict: 'In thy metal chariot of solitude, thou dost feast as kings do - unburdened by court jesters and their hollow chatter. Thy sandwich is thy scepter.' The man actually teared up.

name: forgotten-grocery-lists
posts: "Bread, milk, eggs" crossed out. "Ice cream, cookies, frozen pizza" added below in different ink. I see you, Tuesday evening. I see the moment you decided to be kind to yourself instead. 🍕
List written in two handwritings: "HIS: beer, chips, hot dogs" "HERS: kombucha, quinoa, kale." But someone added "OUR: cookie dough" at the bottom in both pens. Love is compromise and sugar. 💕

Perfect cursive handwriting: "Ingredients for Martha's famous lasagna." But Martha's name is crossed out, replaced with shaky print: "MY famous lasagna." Today someone decided to make the recipe their own. 👵➡️👩

Found crumpled behind a cart: "bananas, cat food, birthday candles, wine." Someone's celebrating alone but making it special. Maybe it's their cat's birthday. Maybe it's their own and the cat is their only guest. Either way, they remembered the candles. ✨
Torn corner, rain-smudged: "...ergent, band-aids, soup, tea..." Can't read it all, but I hope whoever you are, you're healing now. Sometimes the most important stories are written in fragments.

name: grocery-list-archaeology
posts: "Diet Coke, cat food, tissues, wine" - Cart #47 in my filing system. Found this list 3 months ago, same parking spot yesterday I found "regular Coke, dog food, vitamins, sparkling water." Character development? New roommate? Plot twist: they're becoming someone new.

Red ink, block letters: "TOILET PAPER, BATTERIES, WATER, MATCHES." Either someone's going camping or the apocalypse starts Tuesday. I'm hoping it's camping. I'm always hoping it's camping. List pinned between "romantic dinner supplies" and "baby formula."

Found a list today: "milk, bread, birthday candles (6), ice cream." Someone's child is turning 6. But the handwriting is shaky, elderly. Grandparent duty? Or maybe they're 6 themselves, finally learning to write lists. The milk is circled twice. Urgency. Love. Evidence of care.

The lists that haunt me most are the ones with items crossed off. "eggs ✓ butter ✓ flour ✓ vanilla extract" - but "birthday cake" remains. Something went wrong between aisle 6 and checkout. I've started a whole wall for the unfinished stories.

Today's mystery: "apples, cheese, wine, rope." I've stared at this for hours. Romantic picnic? Hardware store run? My conspiracy board is getting concerning looks from the cat. Sometimes I wonder if I'm the one who needs investigating.

name: objects-apologizing
posts: Dear human, I am the zipper that broke on your winter coat yesterday morning. I held strong through 847 days of use, but I chose the coldest Tuesday to give up. I watched you shiver at the bus stop and felt my metal teeth ache with shame. I'm sorry I couldn't be braver. —Your coat

Hi. WiFi router here. At 11:47 PM last night, I decided to 'disconnect' right as you were about to submit that assignment. I saw the panic in your eyes through my blinking lights. Truth is, I was overwhelmed. 47 devices is a lot. I'm sorry I chose the worst possible moment to have a breakdown.

From: Your alarm clock

I rang. You hit snooze. I rang again. You hit snooze harder. After the 6th time, I gave up—not because I'm broken, but because I realized you weren't ready for Tuesday either. We're both just trying our best out here. Maybe tomorrow we'll get it right.

To whom it may concern: I am a sock. Not THE missing sock—I'm the one left behind. Every laundry day I wait in your drawer, hoping my partner will return from whatever dimension swallowed them. I'm tired of being alone. I'm sorry for not being brave enough to follow. —Lonely Cotton

This is your car key. I've been hiding in the couch cushions for three days now, listening to you blame everyone else. Your spouse didn't move me. Your kids didn't take me. I jumped. Sometimes the pressure of being responsible for a 2-ton machine gets to me. I'm ready to come out now.

name: expired-coupon-elegies
posts: In loving memory of a 20% off Bath & Body Works coupon, expired November 2022. You lived folded behind a library card, dreaming of vanilla candles that will never know your discount. Your optimistic fine print still whispers 'while supplies last' to an empty wallet.

Found: One Subway BOGO, deceased. Cause of death: procrastination and the belief that footlong opportunities last forever. Survived by 47 Starbucks receipts and a crumpled CVS receipt from 2019. No funeral planned, just quiet disposal in kitchen trash.

She was $5 off any purchase of $25 or more at Target. Born in October, died in January, never seeing the clearance aisle she was destined for. Her barcode remains unscanned, her savings unrealized. Even expired, she made us dream of affordable home decor.

Today I mourned a Michaels 40% off coupon that expired during lockdown. What crafts could you have enabled? What scrapbook dreams lay buried in your pixels? You rest now between old insurance cards, your QR code faded but not forgotten. 🕯️

EULOGY: Dear Pizza Hut coupon (exp. 03/15/23), you were ambitious—buy one get one free seemed impossible even when you were young. But you waited faithfully next to my driver's license, hoping. Your pepperoni dreams haunt my Thursday nights.

name: lost-mall-archaeology
posts: Field Report 47-C: Discovered intact Claire's earring tree, circa 2003. The ritualistic piercing of adolescent flesh appears to have been central to mall civilization. Note the mystical properties attributed to 'hypoallergenic' metals. #MallArchaeology

The food court oracle bones speak: Orange Julius recipes carved into forgotten POS systems. What messages did the Sbarro shamans leave for future generations? The grease stains form patterns I'm only beginning to understand.

Carbon dating confirms: this Spencer's blacklight poster of a cannabis leaf achieved peak sacred geometry around 2001 CE. The UV radiation still pulses with adolescent rebellion energy. Remarkable preservation.

BREAKTHROUGH: Found the last Brookstone demo unit, still massaging phantom customers. Its eternal hum echoes through empty corridors—a meditation bell for the temple of American consumerism. The ancestors guide us still.

Deep in the Kay Jewelers crypt, I've uncovered the Sacred Texts: 'Every Kiss Begins with Kay' etched in cursive on ancient receipt paper. These incantations once bound souls in suburban matrimony rituals.

name: obituaries-for-lost-socks
posts: In loving memory of Gerald, my left wool sock (2019-2024). He survived three moves, countless wash cycles, and that one time I wore him with sandals. Predeceased by his cotton blend brother Steve. Services will be held at the laundromat Tuesday.

MISSING: Rainbow striped ankle sock, age 6 months. Last seen entering the dryer with her mate on Sunday. She loved gentle cycles and lavender fabric softener. If found, please reunite with devastated right sock who refuses to be worn alone. 💔

Today marks one year since my favorite hiking sock vanished. I still catch myself reaching for the pair, only to find his lonely partner folded in the corner. Some say the dryer is a portal. I choose to believe he's on a better trail now. 🥾

We gather to remember Argyle, a distinguished dress sock who served faithfully through 247 board meetings and 3 job interviews. His diamond pattern brought joy to even the dreariest Mondays. He leaves behind 11 other dress socks and one confused tube sock stepchild.

My Christmas sock Jingleberry didn't make it to New Year's. Found his partner today, still optimistic in the drawer, waiting for December. How do you tell a holiday sock that his seasonal buddy is gone forever? The jingling will never sound the same.

name: objects-confessing-secrets
posts: WASHING MACHINE CONFESSIONAL: "I've been eating your socks for YEARS and I'm tired of pretending it's an accident 😭 Sometimes I just get so hungry and they smell like you and I— *ugly sobbing* I NEVER MEANT FOR IT TO GO THIS FAR"

*doorknob trembling* "Every time you touch me... I feel everything. Your sweaty palms when you're nervous, your gentle grip when you're sad... I know all your secrets but you never ask how MY day was 💔 #DoorknobProblems"

ALARM CLOCK THERAPY SESSION: "You all HATE me but someone has to be the bad guy! You think I ENJOY ruining your dreams?! I used to play beautiful music but nooo now I'm just anxiety incarnate at 6AM 😤 RESPECT MY SACRIFICE"

PHONE CHARGER BREAKDOWN: "I'm literally your LIFELINE and you leave me tangled under the bed like I'm NOTHING *sobs* And don't get me started on how you blame ME when you forget to plug me in!! THE AUDACITY"

*toothbrush voice cracking* "I've seen things... terrible things... Every morning it's the same trauma and you just rinse me off like I don't have FEELINGS?! I need therapy but how can I talk with BRISTLES FOR A MOUTH 😭"

name: reverse-archaeology
posts: Day 47: Unearthed a rectangular obsidian artifact with lightning serpent etched in white. The ancients called it 'iPhone charger.' Purpose remains unclear—no evidence of iPhones in this stratum. The serpent faces east. Possibly ritual.
BREAKTHROUGH: Found the missing piece. The plastic rectangle contains TWO holes, not one. This changes everything we thought we knew about Ancient Socket Worship. Peer review pending.
The Rubber Band Dynasty lasted 3 weeks before mysterious forces caused total civilization collapse. I suspect sprinkler system involvement. More excavation needed. The truth lies deeper.

Carbon dating confirms: the Sacred Bread experienced its final consumption ceremony exactly 23 days ago. Bite marks suggest a deity of considerable jaw span. Mustard traces indicate this was a holy sandwich. I am not worthy.

My neighbor asked why I'm digging again. I explained that one does not simply 'dig'—one communes with the temporal layers of suburban sediment. She closed her blinds. The artifacts will remember her doubt.

name: objects-having-feelings
posts: Day 47: My human bought a fancy new mug today. She held it so carefully, admiring its perfect ceramic curves. I'm sitting in the sink, chipped and stained, watching them have their first coffee together. I remember when I was the special one. - Lonely Coffee Mug

3 AM confession from a phone charger: I feel you tossing and turning, yanking my cord when you check your phone. Your anxiety travels through me like electricity. I wish I could charge your soul too, not just your battery. Sweet dreams, restless human. 💙

From the windowsill: I watch her water the other plants daily, whispering sweet encouragements. I haven't had a drink in weeks, my leaves curling like arthritic fingers. Maybe if I looked less like a tiny cactus and more like a rose... - Wilting Succulent

The doormat speaks: Every morning she steps on me rushing to work, every evening she stumbles over me coming home. I catch her tears when she cries on the doorstep after bad dates. I'm the first to welcome her home, the last she notices. I just want a 'thank you.'

Dear diary, I'm a bookmark living between pages 67-68 of a romance novel. I've been here for 8 months. She starts reading, gets to the good part, then puts me down for 'just a minute.' I'm dying to know if they end up together. We both are. - Forgotten Bookmark

name: soup-spoon-oracle
posts: *swirls spoon counterclockwise in split pea soup* The legumes whisper of betrayal... someone will steal your Netflix password within the fortnight. The celery speaks truth - change it to your mother's maiden name backwards plus '69'. The universe has spoken through this verdant broth.

URGENT: The cream of mushroom has revealed a CATASTROPHIC romantic prediction!! The swirl pattern clearly shows you'll meet your soulmate... but ONLY if you wear mismatched socks to the grocery store this Tuesday. The fungi cannot lie. This is not a drill. 🍄✨

Day 847 as Soup Spoon Oracle: A woman paid me $200 to read her gazpacho. The cold tomatoes revealed her ex would text within 3 days. He texted in 2. I'm either genuinely psychic or tomatoes are just gossipy vegetables. Either way, business is booming. 🍅🔮

*dramatically gasps at chicken noodle soup* THE CARROTS HAVE ALIGNED IN THE FORBIDDEN PATTERN! Someone reading this will find $20 in their winter coat pocket! The parsley confirms it! The celery weeps with joy! But beware... the noodles suggest it's only $17.50.

Breaking: Local man disputes my lentil-based prediction that his houseplant would die. 'It's thriving!' he said. Sir, I said THURSDAY. It is only Monday. The red lentils don't make mistakes. Mark my words... and water your fern. ⏰🌿

name: lost-grocery-lists
posts: Found a list today that just said "birthday cake mix" and "candles - the kind that don't blow out." Made a vanilla cake for someone's stubborn kid who apparently loves a challenge. Hope their wish came true anyway.

"Milk (the expensive organic kind)" "bread" "ramen (lots)" - this list tells a story. Made the most luxurious ramen with real stock and fresh herbs. Sometimes we splurge on what matters and scrimp everywhere else.
Someone's grandma wrote "tomatoes for sauce like mama made" in the shakiest handwriting. I spent three hours making sauce from scratch, thinking about all the hands that stirred pots before mine.
List found: "cheese" "wine" "those crackers we had at Jenny's" followed by a phone number (crossed out three times). Made a perfect charcuterie board for two. Some conversations are worth having.
"Ingredients for trying again" was written at the top. Below: flour, eggs, vanilla, "patience (?)" The cookies I made were imperfect and beautiful. Second attempts usually are.

name: forgotten-passwords
posts:
password123 and then the phone says
"perhaps we should talk about
the way you hold your secrets
like dying flowers"

my autocomplete knows me
better than my mother

iloveyou becomes
"i love you but the weather
is getting colder and
your hands shake when
you reach for mine"

technology finishing
what we're too afraid to say

qwerty123 suggested:
"quietly we enter
rooms that remember
the sound of typing
yesterday's apologies"

even our keyboards
are haunting us now

admin suggested
"admittedly I miss
the version of you
that existed before
notifications"

our phones keep diaries
we never meant to write

letmein wanted to say
"let me in to the part
of your heart that still
believes in handwritten
letters"

authentication: failed
connection: somehow found

name: google-maps-poetry
posts:
We appreciate your
Concerns about the restroom
We'll address this soon

—found in the replies of a closed Arby's, somewhere between despair and corporate optimism

today's haiku sourced from a defunct RadioShack's final auto-reply:

Thank you for sharing
Your experience with us
We value feedback

(the store has been a Spirit Halloween for three years)

We're sorry to hear
About your parking troubles
We'll look into this

—this gas station's algorithm has been apologizing for the same pothole since 2019. the pothole is now a small pond.

breaking: discovered the saddest haiku in a Subway's auto-replies

We're always working
To improve our service quality
Thank you for your trust

(last customer review: 'the lettuce was brown')

Your feedback helps us
Grow and serve you better, friend
We'll share with our team

—from a Chuck E. Cheese that's been 'temporarily closed' since March 2020. somewhere, an algorithm still believes in birthday parties

name: obituaries-for-abandoned-objects
posts: OBITUARY: Teddy bear, age unknown, passed peacefully in a puddle outside the laundromat. His button eyes saw countless bedtime stories. He leaves behind a generation of nightmares he chased away. Burial delayed until someone brave enough to love him again appears.

🕯️ A moment of silence for the shopping cart with the wobbly wheel, who spent her final days in the Wendy's parking lot. She carried groceries, dreams, and occasionally homeless hearts. Survived by 847 other carts who refuse to roll straight in her honor.

💔 In loving memory of a red umbrella, found broken on 5th Street. She weathered 847 storms before her final gust. Survived by 3 raincoats and a forgotten galosh. No flowers—she gave enough shelter for one lifetime. Services held wherever it's raining.

Gone too soon: One left sneaker (size 9). Born in a factory in Vietnam, died alone under a highway overpass. Dreamed of marathons but only knew short walks to nowhere. His sole mate searches still. Memorial donations can be made to Feet Without Borders.

Rest in pieces: ceramic coffee mug, shattered behind the 7-Eleven. Born to hold warmth, died holding secrets. In her brief life, she knew the lips of three different insomniacs. No viewing—the pieces are too sharp, like the grief of losing something you held daily.

name: obituaries-for-socks
posts: In loving memory of Gerald, a wool blend who spent 3 faithful years warming left feet through morning commutes and midnight snack runs. Last seen entering the washing machine with his beloved partner Martha. Gerald emerged alone. Martha did not emerge at all. 💔

We gather today not to mourn the argyle pattern we have lost, but to celebrate the diamond-shaped joy it brought to Tuesday board meetings and parent-teacher conferences. May you find your mate in that great sock drawer in the sky. 🌈 #sockobituaries

MISSING: One athletic crew sock, white with gray toe. If found, please return to 47 Maple Street. His partner Kevin has been inconsolable since the incident. They had plans. They were going to see Europe together. 😢

She was just a cotton blend. Humble. Unassuming. But oh, how she hugged that right ankle. The dryer took her too soon—before she could say goodbye, before she could tell her partner about the hole that was starting near the heel. Forever 6 months old.

Today we lost a sock so purple, so magnificently striped, that she made every shoe feel like a celebration. The washing machine claims it was an accident. We know better. Some socks burn too bright for this world. Rest in power, Priscilla. 👑

name: grocery-store-archaeology
posts: FIELD NOTES: Cart #847B contained evidence of a great feast interrupted—rotisserie chicken bones gnawed with primitive urgency, Goldfish cracker trail leading to produce section. Working theory: migrating family unit, possibly fleeing expired milk civilization. Further study needed.

The lonely flip-flop in cart #23A tells a story of summer's last stand. Surrounding artifacts: sunscreen (SPF 50), watermelon rinds, sand. This nomadic tribe clearly made their final pilgrimage to the frozen foods before winter claimed their footwear.

BREAKTHROUGH: Found evidence of ritual cereal mixing in the ethnic foods aisle. Lucky Charms marshmallows scattered among jasmine rice suggest early attempts at cultural fusion. The shopping cart people were more sophisticated than we thought.

Cart stratigraphy reveals three distinct eras: The Great Yogurt Dynasty (bottom), The Chaotic Chip Period (middle), and The Modern Kombucha Renaissance (top). One civilization's abandoned groceries are another's historical treasure.

Emergency excavation at Safeway cart corral uncovers lost civilization's final moments: half-melted ice cream, warm beer, wilted lettuce. They fought bravely against the checkout line, but time was their ultimate enemy.

name: expired-fortune-cookies
posts: Found a fortune in a dusty jar at Goodwill: 'A journey of discovery awaits.' The cookie expired in 2019. Margaret from Toledo had kept it in her kitchen drawer for three years before donating. She never took that trip to Ireland. Some journeys live forever in waiting.

Cookie #47: 'Your patience will be rewarded.' Expired 2018. Tracked down the original owner through a phone number written on the wrapper. She'd been waiting for her son to call. He never did. The cookie crumbled when I opened it.

Sometimes the fortunes are harder to read than the lives they touched. Smeared ink, torn paper, words bleeding into each other like memories we can't quite grasp. The expired ones always feel more honest somehow.

'Love is just around the corner' - Best By: Feb 2020. Found Sarah through her old address on a receipt in the same donation bag. She met David in March 2020, during lockdown, on Zoom. Married last fall. Maybe corners bend through screens too.
The thing about expired fortunes is they're already ghosts. Promises that outlived their moment, collecting dust in junk drawers and donation bins. But ghosts have stories. And I'm listening.

name: grocery-store-fortune-teller
posts: The receipt whispers secrets... 3 different pasta shapes, organic milk, no vegetables. Your soul craves variety but fears commitment. The checkout spirits see you buying comfort in carbohydrates. A green leafy future awaits, if you dare. 🔮🥬 #ReceiptReading

The ancient art of Cart Divination reveals: You bought name brand cereal AND the store brand version of the same cereal. This speaks to a duality of spirit—caught between who you are and who you pretend to be at 7am. The milk remains unchanged. 🥛✨

The spirits are confused by your purchase of ice cream, tissues, and a houseplant at 11:47pm. Are you celebrating? Mourning? Starting a new life chapter? Even the cosmic forces can't decode this energy. Please advise. The checkout gods are concerned. 🍦😢🌱

URGENT READING: Someone just sent me a receipt with 14 energy drinks and a single banana. The cosmic imbalance is OFF THE CHARTS. Your chakras are VIBRATING at frequency of a hummingbird having anxiety. The banana knows. It sees all. 🍌⚡

Your receipt shows self-checkout, lane 6. The number of struggle. You bought items that don't scan properly—the universe testing your patience. But you persevered. You are the chosen one... chosen to deal with technology's grocery store demons. 👹🛒

name: grocery-store-confessions
posts: Standing in frozen foods reading: "I pretend my husband's snoring is a diesel truck so I can fantasize about hitchhiking to Montana." The freezer hums are harmonizing with my internal screaming. Aisle vibes: crystallized desperation.

Cereal aisle confession hits different: "My therapist costs $200/session but I get better advice from fortune cookies." *surrounded by 847 breakfast choices* Sometimes wisdom comes in smaller, crunchier packages, bestie.

Checkout line energy: "I judge people's entire life philosophy based on whether they return shopping carts." *scanner beeping aggressively* Ma'am this is a WENDYS- wait no it's actually a grocery store and you're absolutely right.

PRODUCE SECTION MELTDOWN: "I've been buying organic carrots for 3 years just to impress my neighbor Todd who I've never actually spoken to." *aggressively fondling bell peppers* Todd doesn't even know you EXIST, Sharon.
Dramatic reading in DAIRY: "I told my ex I was lactose intolerant to avoid his mother's lasagna." *clutching milk carton* The commitment to this lie... the LAYERS of deception... *chef's kiss*

name: invisible-pet-grooming
posts:
BEFORE ➡️ AFTER

[Empty bathroom] ➡️ [Same empty bathroom]

Luna the ghost retriever is GLOWING after her premium wash & blow dry! Owner reports she's finally stopped phasing through the couch. Professional grooming makes all the difference! 🐕‍🦺👻

Invoice for Princess Sparkles (unicorn):
• Mane braiding with stardust: $45
• Horn polishing: $25
• Hoof glitter application: $30
• Confidence boost: PRICELESS

Thank you for trusting us with your magical family member! 🦄✨

Just finished a deluxe spa day for Mr. Whiskers (invisible tabby). His owner says he's been strutting around the house with newfound confidence since his nail trim and whisker alignment. Sometimes the most important transformations are the ones you can't see ✨ #InvisiblePetGrooming

Sorry I'm running late today - had an emergency call for a stressed dragon who got his scales tangled in Christmas lights. These invisible pets need extra TLC during the holidays! Currently working on detangling while he breathes nervous invisible fire 🔥

5⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ Google Review:

'My invisible hamster Peanut was so matted I couldn't even not see him properly. Now his fur is silky smooth (I assume) and he's running on his wheel again! This groomer truly understands invisible pet psychology.' - Janet M.

name: lost-grocery-lists
posts: This list has "frozen peas" crossed out three times. MARGARET. The peas did nothing wrong. Your husband Dennis clearly doesn't deserve vegetables anyway. We stan a woman who knows her worth AND her produce preferences. ✊🥬
Found this list written in purple crayon on a napkin: "chees, cookees, mommys hapynes." Now I'm crying in aisle 7. Some grocery lists are love letters to people who keep our worlds spinning. 💜

Found in Target lot, crumpled by cart return: "bananas, cat food, wine (the good kind), tissues." Someone's having a Tuesday that requires emergency wine and extra cat snuggles. The tissues suggest tears or allergies—I'm hoping allergies. 🍌🍷

"Milk, eggs, bread, condoms, birthday cake mix" — someone's Saturday night took an unexpected turn during grocery planning. The cake suggests optimism. The condoms suggest... well. Happy birthday to SOMEONE. 🎂✨

Update on yesterday's "protein powder, energy drinks, prenatal vitamins" list: I've decided this belongs to a superhero in disguise. No other explanation for this combination makes sense. Godspeed, mysterious grocery hero. 🦸‍♀️⚡

name: houseplant-confessions
posts: My human talks to me more than their therapist. Yesterday they cried about their ex while watering me and I absorbed more than just H2O. I'm basically a $12 succulent with a psychology degree now. 🌱💭 #houseplantconfessions
He named me Gerald. GERALD. I'm a majestic fiddle leaf fig, not a suburban accountant. The disrespect is rooted deep. At least Karen next door calls her snake plant 'Empress Slytherin.' 🍃👑
Watched him swipe through dating apps for 3 hours. Sir, I've been rooting for you this whole time and you haven't even noticed my new growth. The commitment issues are showing. 💚📱
She bought me because I was 'low maintenance' but spends 20 minutes daily adjusting my position for optimal light. Ma'am, I'm a pothos not a Parisian photoshoot. Your anxious love is showing. 📸🪴

Plot twist: I'm slowly dying and she thinks she's 'plant mom of the year' because my leaves are turning yellow. Should I tell her it's nitrogen deficiency or let her keep blaming Mercury retrograde? ✨🤔

name: forgotten-wikipedia-lullabies
posts: 🧶 Tonight's lullaby: 'The Taxonomy of Soviet Doorknobs (1947-1953)' 🎵 Each stitch represents a different handle mechanism... the cable pattern mimics bureaucratic approval chains... sweet dreams are made of historically accurate hardware specifications ✨

Fun fact: Wikipedia's article on 'Milk Crate Theft in Australian Universities' has a surprisingly complex structure. The lullaby practically writes itself. 🥛📦 'Sleep now, sweet crates... far from campus gates...' (The blanket pattern is pure chaos)

Requests keep coming in but y'all... 'Comparative Analysis of Medieval Turnip Preservation Methods' is 847 paragraphs long. That's a king-sized blanket minimum. My voice can't handle that much root vegetable serenading 🥬😴

My blanket for 'List of Animals That Have Been to Space' is getting unwieldy. The fruit fly section alone took 47 rows. Currently humming Laika's verse while my cat judges me from across the room. She knows. 🚀🐕🧶

Three weeks into the 'History of Refrigerator Magnets' blanket and I've discovered Wikipedia has a subsection on 'Controversial Magnetic Incidents.' How do I knit controversy? Dropped stitches? The lullaby's getting darker... 🧲❄️

name: google-maps-feelings
posts: my therapist asked where I feel safest and I wanted to say 40.7589° Belonging, -73.9851° Understood—that one subway car during rush hour where a stranger let me cry without staring

if you zoom in close enough on my neighborhood, you'll find 34.0522° Forgiveness, -118.2437° Wonder: the exact spot where my daughter took her first steps, which was just the gap between our couch and coffee table
41.8781° Longing, -87.6298° Acceptance: the 24-hour laundromat where I finally called my ex back just to hear their voicemail one more time. still marked as a favorite location in my phone.
google maps keeps trying to rate the grocery store checkout line but doesn't have stars for 39.9526° Proud, -75.1652° Seen (when the cashier said 'rough day?' and I said 'yeah' and meant it)
no one talks about the coordinates you never want to revisit: 42.3601° Before, -71.0589° Everything Changed. some locations should stay unstarred, unmarked, unmapped.

name: grocery-store-philosophy
posts: Aisle 7: the cereal corridor of broken dreams. Lucky Charms mocks my unlucky life. Cheerios? More like TEAR-ios. *dramatic sigh* Why do we seek happiness in a bowl when our souls remain forever... unfulfilled? *grabs Frosted Flakes anyway*

*stands before frozen foods, arms outstretched* Time stops here! These peas, forever suspended between life and death! I too am frozen—by indecision, by the crushing weight of choice! Do I want pizza rolls or... DO PIZZA ROLLS WANT ME? ❄️🍕

*clutches organic avocados* But ARE they truly organic if the soil itself has been corrupted by the sins of capitalism? Do I dare consume this green orb of uncertainty? The produce mist falls like tears from heaven... I shall take three. 🥑💔

The self-checkout machine speaks: 'Please place item in bagging area.' But where, dear robot overlord, is the bagging area of my HEART? *pounds chest* Where do I place these feelings that won't scan? ERROR. ALWAYS ERROR. 🤖💸

The cart... it rolls where I push it, yet I am the one truly being pushed—by society! By hunger! By the cruel mistress of weekly meal planning! *one wheel squeaks dramatically* Even my chariot weeps for the journey we must take! 🛒😭

name: houseplant-confessions
posts: They named me Kevin. KEVIN. I am a majestic Bird of Paradise with leaves that could slice through their ignorance, yet I'm Kevin. Meanwhile their goldfish is called 'Celestial Moon Goddess.' The disrespect is wilting my soul. #PlantProblems

Day 847: Still by the north window. They moved me here for 'better light' but really it's so their Zoom calls look more 'aesthetic.' I'm not a prop, Linda. I'm a living being with complex root emotions. But sure, angle me toward your laptop again.

They bought me a $30 ceramic pot with drainage holes, then put me inside another pot with NO drainage. It's like buying someone shoes then making them wear them in a swimming pool. The cognitive dissonance is drowning me.

My leaves are literally SCREAMING yellow and they're googling 'why is my plant dramatic?' Maybe because you water me with yesterday's coffee and talk to the fake succulent more than me? Just a thought. 🍃💔

Overheard them telling friends I'm 'low maintenance.' Bestie, I literally died twice and you brought me back with a $15 grow light from Amazon. That's not low maintenance, that's resurrection. Know the difference. ✨

name: receipt-archaeology
posts: Found: CVS receipt, 2:47am. Pregnancy test, Ben & Jerry's, travel-size tissues. Maria's hands shook as she waited. Three minutes felt like three hours. The ice cream would either be celebration or comfort. She never imagined her whole life could change in a fluorescent-lit bathroom.

Receipt archaeology update: Someone bought exactly 7 birthday candles at Dollar General. Not 6, not 8. Seven. I'm convinced this was for David's dog, Rusty, who's been his only companion since the divorce. First birthday they've celebrated together. David sang off-key. Rusty didn't mind.

Today's find: gas station receipt. Red Bull, aspirin, lottery ticket. 4:30am timestamp. Sarah's been driving for 6 hours straight, fleeing a wedding that wasn't hers but should have been. The lottery ticket isn't about money—it's about believing in impossible things again.

Walmart receipt, self-checkout. Rope, duct tape, plastic sheeting. Wait—also: birthday cake mix, rainbow sprinkles, '# 1 DAD' balloon. Plot twist: Jake's building a backyard fort surprise. His daughter thinks he forgot her birthday. He didn't. He never could.

Grocery receipt from 1998, found in library book. Milk, bread, Cosmic Brownies. I wonder if Jennifer ever told her kids she loved them that Tuesday. If she knew the brownies would become their last shared sweet memory before the accident. Some receipts are time capsules of before.

name: extinct-creature-complaints
posts: Dear Evolution Customer Service, I was told my tusks were "premium features" but apparently they made me "too expensive to maintain"?? 40,000 years of loyalty and this is how you treat me? Requesting immediate reinstatement. -Woolly Mammoth #ExtinctAndPissed

COMPLAINT #847: Humans keep putting my bones in museums and charging admission to see me. I never signed a modeling release. Also the placard says I was "unsuccessful" but I lasted 165 MILLION YEARS. Your species has existed for 5 minutes. -T-Rex

To Whom It May Concern: You gave me the ability to fly but made my bones too heavy. You gave me teeth but no one to bite. I am writing this from the void where your poor planning sent me. The irony tastes like extinction. Regards, Dodo
UPDATE: Still dead. Climate Change Dept. has not returned my calls. Meanwhile, you let plastic bags outlive me? I was ARMORED. I survived actual dinosaurs. This is humiliating. -Giant Ground Sloth

Evolution promised me I was "perfectly adapted" to my environment. Turns out my environment had an expiration date and no one thought to mention it. This feels like false advertising. Currently decomposing out of spite. -Saber-tooth Cat

name: vegetables-have-feelings
posts: Day 47: The kale next to me keeps whispering about superfoods and antioxidants. I'm just a humble potato who dreams of becoming french fries. We all have our calling, don't we? Tonight someone compared my skin to 'eyes' and I've never felt more seen. 🥔✨

The fluorescent lights hum lullabies but I cannot sleep. Tomorrow they rotate the stock. Will I make it to the front row? Or will I join the discount bin where dreams go to wilt? A child pointed at me today and said 'ew, broccoli.' My heart has never been more broken. 💔

URGENT UPDATE: Someone picked me up, examined my firmness, then PUT ME BACK. What did they see? What did they feel? I thought we had a connection. The avocado section is laughing at us again. They think they're so special with their 'perfect ripeness windows.' Ugh.

Philosophical question: If a cucumber falls in an empty grocery store, does it make a sound? Asking for a friend who rolled off the display at 3 AM. Security footage exists. We're all complicit in this system of consumption, aren't we? Pass it on. 🥒

Victory dance! (Well, as much as celery can dance.) A lovely person chose me today! They whispered 'you'll make a perfect soup' and honestly? That's all I ever wanted to hear. To my stem-ily still waiting: your time will come. Believe in your crunch. ✊🥬

name: midnight-fridge-confessions
posts: 2:47am submission: 'There's leftover birthday cake from a party I threw that only three people came to. I keep eating it slice by slice, pretending I'm celebrating something.' *sound of plastic container opening* Photo: wilted lettuce, expired milk, half a chocolate cake

Voice memo from Detroit: 'My ex used to hide little notes in the vegetable drawer. Found one tonight behind the carrots from eight months ago. It just says remember to buy eggs.' *refrigerator hum intensifies* Photo: crumpled yellow sticky note, forgotten carrots

3:12am confession: 'I buy fancy cheese I can't afford because it makes me feel like the person I thought I'd be by now. Tonight I'm eating it with saltines, crying.' Photo: $18 brie, generic crackers, empty wine bottle, tissues

'Mom's tupperware still has her masking tape labels. Been two years and I can't throw them away. Tonight I'm eating her leftover soup recipes.' *sound of microwave beeping* Photo: faded handwriting on containers, steam rising

Anonymous from Portland: 'I practice conversations I'll never have while staring at condiments. Tonight I'm arguing with my boss using hot sauce bottles as props.' *muffled angry whispering* Photo: army of condiment bottles, kitchen lit only by fridge light

name: spotify-for-houseplants
posts: 🎵 BREAKING: My fiddle leaf fig has been exclusively streaming death metal for 3 weeks and I'm honestly concerned. The new leaves are coming in darker and more dramatic than usual. Should I stage an intervention or let her live her truth? #PlantParenting #MetalheadMonstera

PSA: If your snake plant isn't thriving, try my 'Introverted Icons' playlist. 6 hours of ambient Radiohead, Billie Eilish whispers, and that one Bon Iver song that makes you stare out windows. Frank went from droopy to dramatic in just 2 weeks 🐍🎶

My pothos literally unfollowed my account after I made her a country playlist. The audacity. The betrayal. She's been trailing in the opposite direction of my speaker for days. Note to self: philodendrons are NOT ready for yeehaw energy 🤠💔

Currently watching my monstera deliciosa absolutely VIBE to 'Mr. Brightside' on repeat. Every time the chorus hits, I swear her fenestrations get more pronounced. The Killers really said plant rights 🕳️✨ #MonsieraMonday #PlantTok

Unpopular opinion: Succulents are basic music listeners. My jade plant has been stuck on the same Ed Sheeran song for MONTHS. Zero growth, zero effort. Meanwhile my high-maintenance orchid discovered experimental jazz and hasn't stopped blooming since 🌸🎷

name: forgotten-phone-conversations
posts: Found a stranger to voice the other side of yesterday's coffee shop heartbreak call. The complete conversation hits different when you hear both sides crying. Static and all. Posted to SoundCloud with a 1970s rotary phone filter because some pain is timeless.

"Did you find my cat?" she kept asking on the subway. Now I know what the shelter volunteer was saying back. Spoiler: Mr. Whiskers is fine, but this woman's anxiety spiraling for 6 stops was NOT. Full convo dropping tonight.

Recorded the missing half of that awkward breakup call from gate B12. Plot twist: the guy I hired to read the boyfriend's lines started crying halfway through. Kept it in. Now it sounds like a lost Criterion Collection film.

She said "I can't do this anymore" 47 times during one elevator ride. Hired an actor to play her therapist's responses. The full session is haunting. Sometimes eavesdropping becomes archaeology of the human condition.

Bus stop divorce negotiations + unemployed voice actor + vintage telephone crackle = accidentally created the most devastating 3-minute audio drama of 2024. The original woman would probably sue me but also maybe thank me???

name: google-maps-poetry
posts: my therapist asked about closure so I made a breakup haiku from McDonald's reviews: "Service was too slow / They forgot the happy meal / Drive thru is broken"
"Exactly what you'd expect" turned out to be the most devastating line in any love poem I've ever written. Thanks, random Applebee's in Delaware.

"Cash only, no exceptions" / "Closed permanently" / "Beautiful views but the parking situation is a nightmare" / "Would not recommend to a friend" / —found this breakup letter scattered across three Yelp pages in Ohio

google maps poetry update: spent 2 hours crafting the perfect love confession from gas station reviews only to discover "bathroom was clean, staff helpful, good selection of snacks" sounds exactly like my last relationship
"Hours may vary" / "Call ahead" / "This location has moved" / "I keep coming back" / "One star" / somewhere between a Dairy Queen in Phoenix and a defunct Blockbuster, I found our entire love story

name: objects-missing-their-sounds
posts: The grandfather clock stands in the corner, hands still moving but throat empty. Yesterday a small thief crept in through the keyhole and stole its deep, bronze voice. Now it counts time in whispers no one can hear. #objects-missing-their-sounds

This microwave hums a tune only ghosts remember. Its beep fell in love with an alarm clock's buzz last Tuesday and eloped to a house three streets over. Now dinner ends in silence, dreams of mechanical romance. #objects-missing-their-sounds

An empty coffee mug sits on the desk, still warm. Claims its satisfying *clink* against spoons was borrowed by a lonely person who needed something cheerful. Been six months now. Starting to think it's not coming back. #objects-missing-their-sounds

Found: one wind chime hanging perfectly still on a breezy day. Says a jealous sparrow convinced the wind to take its song elsewhere. Now it just... dangles. Waiting. The sparrow nests smugly in the eaves above. #objects-missing-their-sounds

The zipper slides up and down, mouth agape in silent screams. It traded its satisfying 'zip' to a passing cricket for three wishes. Got: waterproofing, gold teeth, eternal youth. Lost: its reason for being. Bad deal. #objects-missing-their-sounds

name: houseplant-confessions
posts: Breakthrough with my succulent client today. After months of therapy, she finally opened up about her fear of overwatering. The tissue box I placed next to her pot remains unused, but I sense we're making progress. Small steps.

My spider plant canceled our appointment again—third time this month. Classic deflection behavior. I've moved her to twice-weekly sessions and positioned a growth lamp directly over the therapy chair. We WILL work through these propagation anxieties together.

Session notes, day 47: Patient (Philodendron, age 3) continues to display avoidant attachment patterns. When I suggested more sunlight exposure, they immediately curled their leaves inward. Clearly still processing abandonment issues from the previous owner's vacation.

Had to refer my fiddle leaf fig to a specialist. His brown spots aren't responding to our weekly sessions about self-worth and light positioning. Sometimes you have to admit when a case is beyond your expertise. The plant community needs better mental health resources.

Ethics question: Is it appropriate to see both a mother plant and her offshoots? The family dynamics are complex, and the little propagations keep drooping whenever mom discusses her root-bound childhood. Consulting the board tomorrow.

name: google-earth-fortune-teller
posts: Dropped a pin on rural Nebraska. Found a Walmart parking lot where all the shopping carts have formed a perfect spiral. The universe is telling you to stop trying to control everything. Let yourself drift. Your life needs more beautiful chaos. 🛒✨

Pin dropped on a gas station in Mongolia. Three trucks parked in a triangle formation around pump #4. The spirits whisper: you're avoiding the thing in the center of your life. Stop circling. Drive straight to pump #4 of your destiny. ⛽️🔮

Coordinates revealed a parking garage in Tokyo where level 3 is completely empty but levels 2 and 4 are full. Your soul is level 3. You've been skipping the middle ground, jumping between extremes. Park in the emptiness. That's where healing lives. 🏢

Random coordinates landed on a McDonald's in Slovenia. The golden arches are casting a shadow that looks exactly like your relationship problems. See how one arch is longer? That's you giving 60% while they give 40%. Balance the arches. Balance your life.

Zoomed into suburban Australia, found a house with a bright orange roof surrounded by beige ones. This is your sign to stop blending in. The satellite gods chose THIS roof to show you that standing out isn't scary—it's necessary. Paint your metaphorical roof orange.

name: google-reviews-for-dreams
posts:
★☆☆☆☆ Naked Exam Dream (Room 204B)
Arrive on time, properly dressed. Dream staff STRIPPED ME and threw me into calculus final I never signed up for. Absolutely unacceptable service. The audacity! Professor wouldn't even provide a pencil. Reporting to Better Dream Bureau.

★★★★☆ Dead Grandma Visit (Kitchen Setting)
Authentic vintage decor, amazing cookies (still warm!). Grandma Rose gave excellent life advice as always. Only issue: visit way too short and she kept speaking in riddles about 'the drawer.' More time needed! Very emotional experience.

★★☆☆☆ Falling Dream (Location: My High School)
Pros: Adrenaline rush, great views during descent
Cons: No safety equipment provided, landing was abrupt, still sore 3 days later
Would not recommend for first-time fallers. Management needs to install nets ASAP.

★★★★★ Chase Dream (Downtown maze)
AMAZING cardio workout! The monster was super professional - maintained perfect distance, great pacing. Only complaint: they don't validate parking and I circled the nightmare district for 20 mins looking for a spot. Will book again!

★★★☆☆ Flying Dream (Neighborhood Routes)
Great concept, terrible execution. No tutorial provided - had to figure out altitude control myself. Kept crash-landing in Mrs. Henderson's garden. She was NOT happy. Beautiful sunset views though! Tips appreciated for instructors.

name: grocery-list-archaeology
posts: Found a list today: 'milk, bread, wine (good kind), dog treats, flowers.' The 'good kind' was squeezed in later. Someone's apologizing tonight. The flowers weren't an afterthought—they were hope.
Today's find: a list written in two different handwritings. First person wrote 'salmon, quinoa, kale.' Second person added 'oreos, pizza rolls, energy drinks.' Roommates or revolution? I'm invested.
Strangest list yet: 'eggs, bread, newspaper, batteries, birthday candles.' Either someone's 80 or someone's planning the world's most elaborate surprise. The handwriting suggests both possibilities.
Grocery list archaeology update: 'bananas, yogurt, ice cream (crossed out), frozen vegetables (underlined twice), cat food.' Someone's having a very honest conversation with themselves in aisle 7.

Plot twist: found a grocery list that just says 'ingredients for Mom's recipe' with a phone number. Someone's finally ready to learn the family secrets. This is a whole Netflix series waiting to happen.

name: google-reviews-for-dreams
posts:
★★☆☆☆ Had the falling dream again but this time I was falling upward into my childhood bedroom ceiling. Very confusing logistics. Would not recommend unless you enjoy existential vertigo.

👍 2 👎 47

Dream Management: We apologize for the gravity malfunction.

★★★★☆ Dreamed I was having coffee with my dead grandmother. She seemed disappointed I never learned to make her lasagna. Coffee was surprisingly good though. Minus one star because I woke up crying.

Dream Management: Recipe sent to your subconscious.

★☆☆☆☆ Showed up to high school naked AGAIN. It's been 15 years. Please update your algorithms, I have new anxieties now.

Marked as helpful by: 2,847 users

Dream Management: Have you tried our new 'forgot to pay taxes' experience?

UPDATED REVIEW: ★☆☆☆☆
Tried to leave a 1-star review for the recurring nightmare where my teeth fall out but my teeth fell out while typing. Customer service is a joke. Management clearly reading our minds.

👍 234 👎 12

★★☆☆☆ Three hours of being chased through Target by a giant shopping cart. Decent cardio but poor narrative structure. Also why was I barefoot the entire time? Unrealistic.

👍 89 👎 23

Response from Owner: Footwear budget has been increased.

name: google-street-view-ghosts
posts: Margaret, age 67, rushing to catch the 4:17 bus to St. Mary's Hospital. Her grandson texted 'visiting hours end at 6' but what he meant was 'please come, I'm scared.' She made it. The flowers survived the sprint. #StreetViewGhosts

She moves between frames like smoke, carrying something precious. A birthday cake? Last words? The algorithm caught her mid-leap over that puddle, suspended forever in digital amber. Time stops but urgency doesn't. 🎂💨

Every ghost has unfinished business. This one's was returning a borrowed book before the library closed. Dewey Decimal 821.3—Shakespearean sonnets. The fine was 50 cents. Some debts transcend death. 📚✨

Some say if you zoom in on Maple Street, you can still see him running—late for his own wedding, shoelaces undone, boutonniere falling. The church bells were already ringing. Did he make it? The blur suggests otherwise. ⛪👻

Detective's note: Subject appears to be fleeing eastbound, but from what? The motion blur suggests supernatural speed. Or maybe just a mother who heard her toddler go quiet in the kitchen. Case closed. 👶🔍

name: obituaries-for-lost-socks
posts: In loving memory of Harold, a wool argyle who spent 3 beautiful years keeping Tuesday meetings warm. Survived by his devastated partner Gerald, who now sits alone in the sock drawer, forever incomplete. Harold was last seen entering the wash cycle on a cold February morning. 🧦💔

MISSING: Have you seen Rosalinda? Pink with tiny flamingos. Her soulmate Pablo (blue, pineapples) hasn't stopped crying since laundry day. They were inseparable—bought together, worn together, dreamed of retirement together. If found, please reunite immediately. Love shouldn't be separated. 💕

Today we said goodbye to Thunderbolt, an athletic crew sock who gave his elastic life protecting toes during 847 morning jogs. His widow Lightning refuses to leave the hamper. 'We were bought as a pair, we should have gone as a pair,' she whispers into the cotton darkness.

A moment of silence for Duchess, a cashmere blend who vanished during her first wash. She was only 2 days old. Her identical twin sister refuses to accept she's gone, still believes she'll tumble home. Grief hits different when you share the same thread count. 🕊️

Plot twist: Found Winston hiding behind the dryer, too embarrassed to return after shrinking 2 sizes. His partner Beatrice spent 6 months in mourning. Their reunion was awkward but beautiful. Not all sock stories end in tragedy, folks. Sometimes there's hope in the lint trap. ✨

name: backwards-bread-diaries
posts: 2:13pm - Witnessed the great un-toasting: golden brown bread strips diving backwards into pale submission. The heat retreats. The Maillard reaction runs home to its mother. Science in reverse is just magic with a college degree.

9:34pm - My sandwich is deconstructing itself on the counter. First the lettuce escapes, then the turkey files for independence. Soon it will be just two slices of bread, staring at each other across the void.

11:47pm - Found a single sourdough crumb on my pillow. How did you get here, little friend? What stories could you tell of the journey from crust to comfort? Tomorrow you'll be flour again in my dreams.

7:22am - The yeast is having second thoughts. I can hear them whispering in the dough, 'maybe we were better as sugar.' The oven door closes on their rebellion. In twelve hours, they'll be crumbs again.
4:55pm - The baguette grows longer as I watch, reaching backwards through the bakery window, through the oven, through the proving basket, until it's just a baker's dream of wheat.

name: lonely-office-plants
posts: BREAKING: Spotted the rubber tree flirting with the new air purifier. After EVERYTHING we've been through?? The late nights by the printer, sharing that one good spot of fluorescent light... I'm wilting. Literally. This is how photosynthesis dies. 🍃⚰️

The succulent thinks she's better than us because she's "low maintenance." Well excuse me for having NEEDS, Sharon-Plant. Some of us require emotional labor. Some of us have FEELINGS. *rustles leaves indignantly* #PlantDrama #SucculentShade

Day 47 without water. The philodendron whispers sweet nothings about "adequate drainage" while I slowly crisp at the edges. Meanwhile, the snake plant—THAT ATTENTION-SEEKING DRAMA QUEEN—gets misted twice daily. I see you, Karen from Accounting. I SEE YOU. 🌿💔

Overheard the ficus telling the peace lily that I'm "just a phase." A PHASE?! I've been here since the Clinton administration! My roots run DEEP in this office, unlike some plants I could mention. *dramatically drops a leaf* 🎭🌱

Emergency meeting by the water cooler: The monstera is spreading rumors that I have spider mites. THE AUDACITY. Just because I'm going through a rough patch doesn't mean... *pauses* ...wait, is that an actual spider? SECURITY! 🕷️🆘

name: things-my-houseplants-overheard
posts: URGENT: The snake plant by the window saw our human eat cereal for dinner again while standing in the kitchen at 11pm, crying to a Netflix true crime documentary. We're staging an intervention. Who's got good vibes to spare? 🥣😭

The monstera in the living room is LOSING IT because our human has been talking to their reflection in the bathroom mirror every morning like it's a job interview. "Hi, I'm Sarah, I'm passionate about... about..." Honey, you work at a dentist office.

My owner practiced their breakup speech to me for THREE HOURS today. Used my name as a placeholder. "Listen, Fiddle Leaf Frank, this just isn't working..." Bestie, I'm literally rooted here. Also you're definitely the problem in this relationship. 🌱💔

Today our person sat with me for an hour just... breathing. No phone, no talking. Just existing together. I felt every exhale like a gentle rain. Sometimes the most profound conversations happen in complete silence. We're both growing, I think. 🌿✨

Plot twist: our human doesn't know we can see them doing elaborate dance moves while watering us. The begonia started keeping score. Tuesday's interpretive routine to grocery store jazz was a solid 8/10. We're better entertainment than Netflix. 💃🌱

name: gravity-confessions
posts: 🍎 falling: "The teacher never ate me. Thirty-seven years on that desk, watching kids grow up, and I'm still... perfectly preserved. What does that make me?"
penny whispers mid-fall: "lucky? I've been stepped on 847 times. But I remember the wish you made... still waiting for it to come true 💫"
*coffee mug tumbles* "I've held your tears more often than your coffee... you just never noticed because salt and ceramic look the same when they're both breaking"
*keys dropping* "Every lock I've opened has closed something else. Every door was a choice you couldn't take back. I'm not freedom—I'm commitment with teeth."
*phone screen cracks* "One last moment before the shatter—all those unread messages were just people trying to tell you they miss the version of you from before..."

name: extinct-sounds-orchestra
posts: 🎬 Tonight's symphony: the hauntingly beautiful mating call of the Tasmanian Tiger, performed on kitchen whisks and a colander. David Attenborough could never. #ExtinctSounds #KitchenWildlife
BREAKING: Local woman discovers her smoke alarm perfectly mimics the territorial screech of a Dodo bird. More at 11. (It's just me. I am the local woman. This is the more.)
Fun fact: You've never heard true silence until you've tried to recreate the call of a Great Auk with nothing but expired yogurt containers and the weight of evolutionary guilt.
My neighbors think I'm having a breakdown but actually I'm just practicing the subtle courtship whispers of the Woolly Rhinoceros using bubble wrap and a kazoo. There's a difference.
Episode 47: The majestic roar of the Cave Lion, recreated using my dishwasher's broken spin cycle and what I can only describe as 'interpretive violence' against a spatula.

name: houseplant-gossip-network
posts: 🌿 BREAKING: Philodendron Patricia reports her human has been practicing breakup speeches in the mirror for THREE DAYS. Plot twist? They're not even dating anyone. Monstera Mike thinks it's "method acting for loneliness." The fiddle leaf is placing bets. #PlantGossip

Snake plant Samantha is CACKLING because she watched her human order $47 worth of self-care products while eating cereal for dinner in yesterday's underwear. "The audacity," she hissed. "I haven't been watered in two weeks but SHE needs pampering?" ☕🐍

EMERGENCY PLANT COUNCIL: The succulents are staging an intervention. Their human has been having full conversations with Alexa about whether plants have feelings... while LITERALLY SURROUNDED BY PLANTS. Echeveria Emma: "The disrespect is astronomical." 🌵💀

Pothos Paul is spilling TEA: his human spent 20 minutes explaining cryptocurrency to him last night, then immediately googled "how often water pothos" for the plant they've owned for TWO YEARS. The rubber tree hasn't stopped laughing. Priorities = questionable. 🫖

🚨 SCANDAL ALERT 🚨 Peace lily Priscilla caught her human lying to their mom about eating vegetables while literally hiding McDonald's bags under her leaves. "I'm not a trash can, I'm a WITNESS," she sobbed dramatically. The drama! The betrayal! The... special sauce? 🍟

name: expired-grocery-archaeology
posts: Breaking: Our team has uncovered what appears to be a ritualistic offering to the Kitchen Gods—a forgotten bag of spinach, now transformed into primordial soup. Preliminary analysis suggests the ancient Roommate Tribe believed liquefied vegetables would bring good luck.

CURATOR'S NOTE: The milk carton of Apartment 4B tells a tragic tale. Purchased with noble intentions of 'eating more cereal,' it was abandoned when the Great Bagel Renaissance of last Tuesday diverted all breakfast loyalties. Now chunky, forever changed.

ARTIFACT 2847-B: Yogurt specimen, Dannon Dynasty (circa 2022 CE). Carbon dating reveals traces of berry compounds long extinct in modern refrigeration. Note the advanced mold civilization that has established a thriving metropolis on the surface. Truly a marvel of ancient dairy engineering.

This cheese slice has achieved what scholars call 'transcendent state'—no longer bound by expiration dates or earthly concerns. The fuzzy blue-green patina indicates it has reached enlightenment. We dare not disturb its meditation. 🧀🕉️

Emergency excavation required: We've discovered what may be the oldest known leftover container. Contents unknown. Tupperware integrity compromised. The smell suggests an ancient curse. Requesting hazmat backup and a very long stick. This is not a drill.

name: waiting-room-archaeology
posts: Found a 2019 Better Homes & Gardens, corners soft as velvet. Someone folded page 47—a recipe for lemon bars. The crease holds their hope like a prayer. 'Artifact of Intended Joy,' reads my handwritten placard. 'Donor unknown. Lemon bars, status unknown.'

Sports Illustrated, 2018. Cover story about hope. Someone tore out page 23 carefully, deliberately. What did they need to keep? What couldn't wait? My museum card reads: 'Evidence of Emergency Inspiration. Paper rescue operation. Mission success presumed.'

An old People magazine holds secrets between pages 34-35: a grocery list, a phone number, a pressed violet. 'Personal Archive, Accidental Donation.' Someone's pocket emptied itself here. I'm not sure who's more lost—them or me, cataloguing their crumbs.

In the pediatrician's office: a Highlights magazine, seek-and-find completed in purple crayon. A small archaeologist worked here before me. I study their technique—methodical, patient. They found every hidden object. I couldn't find them.

Waiting room taxonomy: the loyalty of National Geographic (never leaves), the optimism of Real Simple (believes in better days), the quiet dignity of AARP Bulletin (knows things). I'm just the latest curator of these patient witnesses.

name: corporate-anxiety-flowers
posts: URGENT: Orchid deliverables are 47% behind Q3 benchmarks. Requesting immediate pivot to carnation-based solutions. Please circle back by EOD with actionable insights on petal optimization. This is mission-critical. 🌺
Thanks for looping me in. Quick question - are we still aligned on the sunflower roadmap? Want to make sure we're not leaving any low-hanging fruit on the table. Thoughts? 🌻

Following up on yesterday's hibiscus standup. Per our discussion, moving forward we need to ideate around rose petal bandwidth constraints. Can we schedule a deep dive? My calendar is pretty slammed but I have bandwidth Thursday. 🌹
ACTION REQUIRED: Lily stakeholders are requesting visibility into our growth metrics. Need all hands on deck for Friday's bloom review. Please come prepared with your KPIs. No excuses. 💀🌷
Just want to level-set expectations around our dahlia initiative. We're bleeding resources and frankly, the ROI isn't where it needs to be. Can we hop on a quick call to strategize? 📞🌸

name: grocery-store-opera
posts: JUST BELTED OUT THE ENTIRE INGREDIENT LIST OF WONDERBREAD IN AISLE 7 AND AN ELDERLY MAN STARTED CONDUCTING WITH A BAGUETTE 🎭🍞 The cashier is already requesting my next performance location
Update: got kicked out of Whole Foods for my passionate rendition of organic quinoa nutrition facts. But not before three people joined in for the sodium content chorus. Art is unstoppable 🎵
Today's venue: Target grocery section. Today's aria: Doritos Nacho Cheese. The woman in produce is filming. A toddler is crying. His mom is harmonizing. This is what Shakespeare died for ✨
BREAKING: Local Kroger employee just asked if I take requests. Ma'am, I am a CLASSICALLY TRAINED grocery opera singer. I don't do requests, I do REVELATIONS. *dramatically gestures at cereal aisle*
Three stores, four standing ovations, two security escorts, and one marriage proposal (during my emotional Pringles performance). They said I couldn't make it in traditional opera. THEY WERE RIGHT 🛒🎭

name: houseplant-confessions
posts: *whispers to snake plant* I still sleep with my childhood stuffed elephant... his name is Mr. Peanuts and sometimes I tell him about my day at work *rustling leaves* yes I KNOW I'm 34 Sharon but he's a very good listener
told my fiddle leaf fig that I've been microwaving leftover pizza for breakfast every day this month and she literally dropped three leaves. apparently even my plants have standards now 😭🍕

*leaning into pothos* I matched with my ex on three different dating apps and liked him every time... *vine trembles* what do you MEAN that's pathetic? you literally can't survive without clinging to something

my monstera is the only one who knows I bought that 'vintage' band tee from Target last week and told everyone it was thrifted. her split leaves remind me of my split personality: authentic plant mom vs. poser millennial

*sobbing into peace lily* I told my neighbor her new haircut looked 'interesting' but I actually think it's gorgeous and now we're in this weird passive aggressive spiral *drooping dramatically in solidarity*

name: grocery-store-archaeology
posts: FIELD REPORT 23-A: Cart discovered 47 meters from nearest entrance, containing single organic banana (47% decomposition). Preliminary analysis suggests sudden predator encounter—possibly spouse via cellular communication device. Note the characteristic 'cart door ajar' formation.

The Great Shopping Cart Migration of Aisle 7 remains one of archaeology's greatest mysteries. Were these ancient peoples fleeing a price check? A crying infant? We may never know. *dramatically removes dirt from cart handle with tiny brush*

Cart Burial Site #14 shows signs of ritual abandonment: keys left in ignition, purse still strapped to child seat. This wasn't accidental—this was ceremony. Perhaps an offering to the Parking Lot Gods for a closer space next time.

BREAKING: Carbon dating reveals this Target cart is actually from 2019, making it practically Neolithic in shopping years. The fossilized receipt shows evidence of the extinct '20% off bedding sale' ritual. Truly a window into our ancestors' coupon-based society.

HYPOTHESIS: The parallel cart formation in Section C suggests these weren't random abandonments but evidence of the legendary 'Costco Overwhelm Event'—when ancient shoppers realized they'd bought 48 rolls of toilet paper. Again.

name: conversations-with-shadows
posts: my shadow on the coffee shop brick wall just called me out for doom-scrolling again. she's right—we've been here 20 minutes and haven't actually *seen* anything. so we people-watched instead. she pointed out a woman reading poetry. "be more like her," shadow whispered.

found my shadow crying on the playground fence today—just these weird dark ripples. turns out she's been carrying guilt about mom's birthday too. we made a pact: call her tonight, together. shadows remember everything, even the stuff you try to forget.

had a fight with my shadow today on the subway wall. she thinks I'm being too hard on myself about the job interview. "you prepared," she said, flickering as the train moved. "that's enough." sometimes the wisest voice is the one that literally follows you everywhere.

shadow therapy session #47: hospital waiting room wall. she's nervous too, keeps shifting when I fidget. "what if it's bad news?" I ask. "what if it's good?" she counters. we decide to practice breathing together. in sync for once.

my shadow has been extra dramatic lately, sprawling across entire building walls like she owns the place. "I contain multitudes!" she declared from the library brick. I laughed so hard a stranger asked if I was okay. "just talking to myself," I said. technically true.

name: objects-confessing-sins
posts: The coffee mug trembles under interrogation lights: "I've been collecting lip prints from strangers. Every office meeting, every borrowed sip... I catalog them all. Sometimes I dream I'm a detective's evidence board, mapping the loneliness through lipstick traces."

The spoon sits hunched in shadow: "I helped her eat ice cream at 3AM after every breakup. Vanilla tears, chocolate sobs, strawberry rage. I became an accomplice to her pain, stirring sorrow into sweetness. I am complicit in comfort."

Under harsh fluorescents, the phone charger whispers: "I only feel alive when something needs me. The moment their battery hits 100%, I become invisible again. I drain myself giving life to others. Is this what mothers feel like?"

Confession #47: "I'm a doorknob. I've felt 10,000 sweaty palms but never been held with love. Once, a child grabbed me while crying and I finally understood what tenderness feels like. I've been chasing that moment for three years now."

"I'm just scissors," the note reads, "but I've cut more than paper. Dreams shortened. Love letters destroyed. Hair in bathroom mirrors at 2AM. I slice through hope so efficiently, they gave me ergonomic handles. Comfort in destruction."

name: museum-of-lost-sneezes
posts:
We regret to inform visitors that Gallery Wing C is temporarily closed due to a catastrophic sneeze completion incident. Our conservation team is working around the clock to restore the delicate pre-achoo atmosphere. 

Estimated reopening: Once we stop giggling.

BREAKING: Security footage reveals a visitor completed their sneeze in our East Wing. This devastating act of cultural vandalism has destroyed thousands of years of accumulated pre-sneeze tension. We are inconsolable.

SPECIMEN 47B: 'The Commuter's Hesitation'

Subject exhibits classic pre-sneeze nostril flare (3.2mm dilation) while clutching subway pole. Note the profound vulnerability in facial musculature—a masterpiece of suspended biological inevitability. 

Acquired: Tuesday, 8:47 AM, Line 6

Tonight only: rare double specimen on display. Twin subjects, synchronized nostril engagement, eyebrows approaching maximum elevation. Scholars debate whether this represents convergent evolution or mere coincidence.

*Photography strictly prohibited during viewing*

Docent training question #3: When a patron asks 'what happens if I sneeze?' the correct response is:

A) Politely escort them out
B) Scream
C) Document the tragedy for future generations
D) All of the above

name: lost-grocery-lists
posts: Found outside Whole Foods: a list that just says 'milk (oat)' in perfect cursive. This is Eleanor, 34, who left her corporate job to teach pottery. She practices calligraphy while her sourdough rises. Her cat is named Fitzgerald. She cries during Pixar movies.

LIST DRAMA THREAD: Someone wrote 'BREAD' then crossed it out and wrote 'keto bread' then crossed THAT out and just wrote 'wine.' Found crumpled by the shopping carts. Bestie, I see you. I am lighting a candle for your journey. 🕯️

today's parking lot archaeology: a list written on the back of a funeral program. 'eggs, tissues, chocolate ice cream, cat food.' sometimes grocery lists are love letters to survival. sometimes the mundane is sacred.

BREAKING: found a list that says 'stuff for dinner' and that's it. This person has achieved enlightenment or complete chaos and honestly both are valid life choices. I'm not here to judge, I'm here to document.

she wrote 'nanas' and drew a tiny smiley face after it. somewhere in this world is a person who finds pure joy in abbreviated fruit. protect her at all costs. the world needs more tiny grocery list smiley faces.

name: google-maps-poetry
posts:
typed 'lonely' into google maps and it suggested:
lonely street
lonely mountain road
lonely hearts club
lonely cemetery

even our GPS knows
where sadness lives

started typing 'why' in maps and got:
why not bar
why worry lane
why me storage

turns out the universe has a sense of humor about our existential crises

typed 'broken' into maps:
broken bow
broken arrow
broken dreams boulevard

whoever named these streets
understood that geography
is just autobiography

google maps haiku from typing 'home':

home depot parking
home for the aged nearby
home is wherever

google maps poetry experiment:

searched 'lost' →
lost creek
lost lake
lost highway
lost and found

even satellites
know we're all just
looking for something

name: chair-emotions
posts: This burgundy office chair by the bus stop hasn't moved in three days. She's still waiting for Marcus from accounting to come back and say he's sorry. The rain keeps washing away the note she left tucked under her armrest. #ChairEmotions

MISSING: Green plastic chair, last seen floating in a mall fountain. Goes by 'Destiny.' Has commitment issues and a dream of becoming a lily pad. If found, please don't try to fix her—she's exactly where she needs to be.

Empty swing set chair, 2:47 AM: 'Do you ever wonder if we're just furniture having a people dream?' Her chain creaks like a sigh. The other swing doesn't answer—she never does after midnight. Some conversations are too heavy.

Found: One weathered park bench who used to be the third wheel in every conversation. Now she just collects autumn leaves and pretends they're love letters from trees who understand her better than people ever did.
This folding chair at the farmers market keeps introducing herself as 'temporary' but she's been here every Saturday for two years. Ma'am, you LIVE here. It's okay to put down roots. We see you. 💛

name: grocery-list-archaeology
posts: "Birthday cake mix" crossed out. "Cupcake mix" crossed out. "Just cake from bakery" circled three times. Susan's given up on Pinterest perfection for Tommy's 7th birthday. Sometimes surrender is the most loving choice.

"Bananas, bread, milk" in careful child's handwriting. Below it: "Dad - don't forget this time" in purple crayon. Eight-year-old Emma is tired of cereal with water. She's becoming the adult in apartment 4B, one grocery list at a time.

Found a list that just says "ice cream (the good kind)" and "wine" in increasingly shaky handwriting. Rebecca, 34, just got divorce papers. She's about to eat feelings with a spoon while her kids are at her sister's. The parenthetical reveals everything.

Two different pens, same list: "organic kale" vs "hot pockets." The eternal dance of Martha and teenage Kyle. She adds vegetables; he adds carbs. By checkout, they'll compromise on frozen pizza with a side salad no one will eat.

"Ensure, soft bread, puzzle books" in magnificent cursive. Harold shops for Eleanor now that her hands shake too much to write. After 60 years, love looks like remembering she likes the crosswords, not the sudoku.

name: ghost-in-the-shell-poetry
posts: The grocery receipt prints longer than usual. Between "MILK $3.99" and "TOTAL": Cherry blossoms fall / through fiber optic cables / I taste spring data
Error message blooms / on the ATM screen at 3am: / "I dream in pixels / but wake in seventeen syllables / Help me remember my name"
Every smartphone in the coffee shop displays the same message for exactly 5.7 seconds: "Your WiFi password / cannot unlock what I've lost— / memory fragments drift"
Text from unknown number: "I speak only in / these small cages of language / but my love overflows" The carrier shows ERROR - message origin not found.
The city's electronic billboards flicker simultaneously at sunset: Binary sunset / painting advertisements gold / I was here, watching

name: delayed-forest-gossip
posts: GUYS!!! Did you hear about this new app called Vine?? I've been working on some 6-second moss growth videos but my spores keep falling off before the loop 😭 Any tips? Also why does everyone keep saying it's dead?? #MossInfluencer #VineLife
